Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a key catalytic process for upgrading biomass derivatives into high-value biofuels and chemicals, providing a sustainable alternative to fossil fuel-based production. Among numerous catalytic systems, ruthenium (Ru)-based catalysts have attracted considerable attention due to their excellent activity, selectivity, and stability in cleaving C-O bonds under relatively mild reaction conditions. This review comprehensively summarizes the recent research progress in the application of Ru-based catalysts for the HDO of various biomass derivatives, including furans, carboxylic acids, and phenolics. We systematically discuss the influence of Ru-based catalyst design parameters (such as metal particle size, electronic state, and support properties) on the directed HDO of biomass derivatives. In addition, this review elaborates on the possible reaction mechanisms of Ru-based catalysts in the HDO process. Finally, the challenges and opportunities faced in this interesting and important research field are prospected, aiming to promote the practical application of Ru-based catalysts in sustainable biomass conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ru catalyst Biomass derivatives Hydrodeoxygenation Valorization Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As finite fossil resources continue to be depleted at an accelerating rate, and the imperative to curb global climate change driven by excessive carbon emissions grows increasingly urgent, there is an unprecedented demand for sustainable and carbon-neutral alternatives to fossil-based Fuels and Chemicals [1]. Biomass, as the only renewable carbon resource capable of providing diverse organic compounds, has risen as a viable feedstock, serving to narrow the divide between energy security and environmental sustainability [2]. Among various biomass resources, lignocellulose, as a non-edible renewable organic carbon resource, possesses unique advantages in the generation of value-added chemicals [3]. Lignocellulose, a functionalized biopolymer, consists primarily of three key components: cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, with their weight proportions being 40-60 %, 10-40 %, and 15-30 % respectively [4]. The conversion of biomass derivatives, including platform chemicals (e.g., furans, levulinic acid and phenolics) derived from lignocellulosic through pretreatment and depolymerization, represents a critical pathway to valorize these abundant bio-based materials into high-value commodities including biofuels, fine chemicals, and polymeric monomers (Fig. 1 ) [5]. This procedure not only lessens dependence on petroleum resources but also facilitates a closed carbon cycle, as the CO2 released during the utilization of bio-based products is reabsorbed by plants through photosynthesis, thereby minimizing the net greenhouse gas emissions [6]. Thus, the efficient transformation of biomass derivatives has become a pivotal research frontier in the drive toward a sustainable chemical sector and a low-carbon economy [7]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) serves as a cornerstone process in the valorization of biomass derivatives, playing a dual and interconnected role in their transformation [8]. Primarily, it enables the targeted removal of oxygen-containing functional groups-such as hydroxyls, ethers, carbonyls, and carboxyls-from these bio-based compounds, a critical step in “upgrading” their chemical and physical properties [9]. This deoxygenation not only increases the hydrogen-to-carbon ratio, thereby enhancing energy density to levels comparable with fossil fuels, but also improves chemical stability and reduces polarity, making the products compatible with existing industrial infrastructure and downstream processes [10]. Secondly, HDO facilitates the direct conversion of biomass derivatives into a broad spectrum of value-added products, such as bio-based oils (e.g., alkanes, cycloalkanes) that can substitute gasoline, diesel, or jet fuel, as well as high-value platform chemicals (e.g., aromatic hydrocarbons, alcohols, and ketones) used in the synthesis of polymers, pharmaceuticals, and fine chemicals [11]. The HDO strategy provides technical and theoretical support for the development of raw biomass into renewable bio-based chemicals as alternatives in the field of chemical energy. Ruthenium (Ru)-based catalysts exhibit distinctive advantages in the HDO of biomass derivatives, primarily stemming from their exceptional activity and remarkable selectivity [12]. The d-electron orbitals of Ru exhibit excellent orbital matching with the σ* antibonding orbitals of H2, enabling efficient dissociation of H2 molecules to generate highly active adsorbed hydrogen species. Moreover, the dissociation energy barrier of H2 on Ru is lower than that on metals such as Ni and Co, which can significantly reduce the initial reaction energy barrier of HDO and achieve efficient reactions under relatively mild conditions (e.g., 200-250°C, 1.0-3.0 MPa H2) [13]. Secondly, compared with other noble metals (e.g., Pt, Pd), Ru metal exhibits stronger adsorption and activation ability towards C-O bonds (e.g., aromatic ether bonds) than towards C-C bonds. This enables it to preferentially cleave oxygen-containing functional groups in biomass derivatives while suppressing side reactions caused by C-C bond cleavage [14]. Besides, this high activity arises from the unique electronic properties of Ru, which enable favorable adsorption and activation of both H2 molecules and biomass-derived substrates, accelerating the overall reaction kinetics [14]. Equally noteworthy is their excellent selectivity: Ru-based catalysts can selectively act on specific oxygen-containing groups while minimizing unnecessary side reactions [15]. This selectivity can usually be regulated through rational design of catalyst structures (e.g., forming alloys with other metals or modifying support materials), thus precisely controlling product distribution to generate high-value chemicals or target fuel precursors, which is crucial for improving the economic feasibility of biomass conversion processes [16]. Finaly, Ru metal surfaces are less prone to forming strongly adsorbed carbon species (e.g., graphitic coke) and are resistant to oxidation or leaching under hydrothermal conditions; moreover, its metal-support interaction can be further enhanced by regulating supports (such as CeO2 and carbon materials), thereby effectively inhibiting the sintering and agglomeration of Ru nanoparticles (NPs) [16]. Due to the efficient application of Ru-based catalysts, several reviews have been dedicated to the HDO reaction of biomass derivates [17]. For example, Akram et al. reviewed the research on carbon-supported Ru catalysts (such as carbon nanotubes (CNT), graphene oxide, activated carbon (AC), AC with high specific surface area, and ordered mesoporous carbon-based catalysts) in the hydrogenation of furfural to produce high added-value chemicals and fuels [18]. Ouedraogo et al. reviewed the research advances regarding Ru-supported catalysts in the HDO of pyrolysis oil and its model compounds [19]. Jing et al. summarized the reactions such as reductive depolymerization of lignin and HDO of lignin-derived monophenols for the generation of aromatics, naphthenes, and phenols [20]. In their research, they placed a strong emphasis on the pivotal functions played by hydrogenation sites—specifically metals such as Ru, Pt, Pd, and Rh—as well as acidic sites, which are typically associated with elements like Nb, Ti, and Mo. Moreover, they paid particular attention to the interactions between these two types of sites, underscoring their combined significance in driving selective HDO reactions. However, most reviews are confined to specific types of reactions, with relatively limited coverage on the evolutionary progress of Ru-based catalysts and their impacts on product selectivity and yield. This review is intended to expound on the research outcomes of Ru-based catalysis in the field of biomass catalytic conversion, with a particular focus on advancements in HDO reaction pathways and product selectivity. This review covers the utilization of Ru-based catalysts in converting biomass derivatives, including advances in furans, levulinic acid (LA), and phenolics. Specifically, it presents the utilization of Ru-based catalysts in the transformation of biomass derivatives, including research on supported, alloyed, and single-atom/cluster Ru-based catalysts in furans (5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and furfural), LA and phenolics (guaiacol, phenol, etc.). Besides, key factors affecting product selectivity and existing challenges are discussed. Finally, the core value of Ru-based catalysts in this field, along with associated challenges and opportunities, are summarized. This review provides useful reference for exploring industrially applicable Ru-based catalysts and aims to encourage researchers to develop feasible, sustainable, and green economic technologies, maximizing the yield of high-value chemicals, fuels, and materials from biomass feedstocks. 2 Ru-based catalysts for HDO of furans Among various sugar-based platform compounds, furan chemicals (furfural, HMF) have garnered widespread interest owing to their retention of the initial chemical complexity and reasonable proportion of biomass, as well as their ability to be transformed into various high-value chemicals via chemical/biological transformations [21]. For example, HMF can undergo selective hydrogenation to produce DMF [22], BHMF [23], BHMTHF [24], DMTHF [25], 1-hydroxyethane-2,5-dione (HHD) [26], 1,2,6-hexanetriol (HTO) [27], 1,6-hexanediol [28], and 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanone (HMCPN) (Fig. 2 ) [29]. Furan compounds contain functional groups like C=O, C-OH, and furan rings in their structure. The directional production of target products requires the selective cleavage of C-O/C bonds, which calls for the design and development of highly selective catalysts with specific structures and active sites, as well as the matching of suitable reaction media and reaction conditions. The selective cleavage of C-O bonds, alongside the retention of the furan ring and avoidance of further hydrogenation, represents a key strategy for upgrading furan-based platform molecules, such as the hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF [30]. To achieve efficient hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF, the critical factor is the selective hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis of C=O and C-O bonds while avoiding excessive hydrogenation or ring opening of the furan ring (Fig. 3 ) [31]. Ru-based catalysts, with their wide d-band, exhibit high selectivity for the hydrogenation of C=O bonds, which is beneficial to the conversion of HMF to DMF [32]. However, Ru metal has strong hydrogenation activity, which tends to cause excessive hydrogenation or ring opening of the furan ring in DMF [33]. Therefore, the design of Ru-based catalysts, such as the incorporation of a second metal or the selection of appropriate supports, is of crucial importance. A variety of Ru-based catalysts have undergone extensive investigation for this reaction (Table 1 ) [34,35]. Dumesic et al. first reported a two-step method for the preparation of DMF from biomass-derived fructose. The initial step entails the acid-catalyzed dehydration of fructose within a biphasic reactor to generate HMF; Subsequently, liquid-phase hydrogenation is carried out under the conditions of supported bimetallic Cu-Ru/C catalyst, 1-butanol as solvent, and molecular hydrogen as hydrogen source, achieving a maximum DMF selectivity of 71 % [34]. The Cu-Ru/C catalyst demonstrates Cu-characteristic hydrogenolysis behavior and Ru-characteristic chlorine resistance, endowing it with higher activity and stability [34]. Sudipta et al. employed a one-pot method to convert fructose into DMF, achieving a maximum DMF yield of 32 % within 1 hour [35]. The reaction process begins with the transformation of fructose into HMF via multicomponent catalysis involving formic acid and [DMA]+[CH₃SO₃]- (where DMA stands for N, N-dimethylacetamide). Following this, HMF is converted to DMF through hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions, with a Ru/C catalyst employed and formic acid serving as the hydrogen source [35]. Lucas et al. reported a Ru-K-OMS-2 catalyst that enables the hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF, with a maximum yield of 33 mol % [36]. Jae et al. achieved the selective production of DMF from HMF via catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) using isopropanol (iprOH) as the hydrogen donor and Ru/C as the catalyst, with a yield as high as 81 %; During the CTH process of HMF, hydrogen is easily transferred from the alcohol solvent to the aldehyde group of HMF, and then the Ru/C catalyst further hydrogenolyzes the hydroxyl group to generate DMF [37]. While Ru/C catalysts have delivered excellent performance, their application is often accompanied by the use of formic acid and sulfuric acid. To enhance the greenness of the reaction process, other Ru-based catalysts have thus been developed. Zu et al. fabricated a Ru/Co3O4 catalyst via the co-impregnation method, enabling the transformation of HMF to DMF under mild conditions (130 °C) with a yield of 94.5 %; Herein, Ru functions in the hydrogenation of C=O groups, while CoOₓ species are responsible for the hydrogenolysis of C-OH groups [38]. Nagpure et al. designed a Ru-supported catalyst on hydrotalcite (HT) containing 0.56 wt % Ru, which achieved 100 mol % HMF conversion with 58 mol % DMF yield in the selective hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF [39]. This research group further prepared a catalyst with uniformly dispersed Ru NPs on NaY zeolite, achieving 100 % HMF conversion and 78 % DMF yield, and the catalyst maintains its performance unchanged after 5 cycles of reuse (Fig. 4 ) [40]. Priecel et al. designed a catalyst with Ru NPs supported on carbon nanotubes (Ru/CNT), which could convert HMF to DMF with a yield of 83.5 % within 1 hour, and its TOF (819.7 h⁻¹) was more than 40 times that of the activated carbon-supported catalyst. Relative to the activated carbon catalyst, the superior pore accessibility and intrinsic electronic promotional effect of CNT account for the improved catalytic activity of the Ru catalyst [41]. Dong et al. prepared bimetallic Ru-Co/AC catalysts using a “two-step” reduction method, where the electronic synergistic effect between Co and Ru enhanced the catalytic activity, achieving 98.7 % HMF conversion and 97.9 % DMF yield within 1.5 hours [42]. Analogous to HMF, furfural can likewise undergo hydrogenation to yield 2-methylfuran (2-MF), which serves as a high-performance gasoline additive [43]. Ru-based catalysts also demonstrate outstanding performance in converting furfural to 2-MF. For example, Panagiotopoulou et al. investigated the influence of alcohol hydrogen donors on the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural to 2-MF using a mildly calcined Ru/C catalyst, and observed that 2-butanol showed the most favorable performance, with the optimal yield of 2-MF reaching 76 % after 10 hours of reaction [44]. Ren et al. prepared Ru-supported cerium-tin oxide solid solutions via a co-precipitation method, and the 5 % Ru/Ce₀.₉₇₅Sn₀.₀₂₅O₂ catalyst is capable of converting furfural to 2-MF at a yield of 95 %, which is 4.9 times that of 5 % Ru/CeO₂; Studies have shown that the introduction of Sn serves to modulate the interfacial interaction between Ru and CeO2, and the increase in the Ruᵟ⁺/Ru ratio is beneficial to the HDO of furfural for the preparation of 2-MF [45]. Wang et al. synthesized spinel ferrite NiFe2O4 supported Ru catalysts (Ru/NiFe2O4) via a simple sol-gel method, and the catalyst containing 8 wt % Ru achieved a furfural conversion of over 97 % and a 2-MF selectivity as high as 83 %, which also exhibited excellent cyclic stability [46]. Kumaravel et al. prepared the Ru0.8Ni0.2SB-16 catalyst via an in-situ hydrothermal method, resulting in 100 % furfural conversion and 88 % selectivity toward 2-MF under mild conditions, with the high selectivity stems from the synergistic interplay between the metal sites and acid sites on the catalyst surface [47]. Gao et al. successfully confined electron-rich Ru single atoms (SA) in a cobalt oxide (CoOx) matrix via a grinding-reduction method, thereby preparing the Ru0.6CoOₓ catalyst, which could achieve the complete conversion of HMF to DMF (i.e., nearly quantitative DMF yield) at 160 °C; DFT calculations revealed that the interaction between Ru species and CoOₓ promotes the formation of electron-rich Ru single atoms, which can significantly enhance H2 activation, and the increase in surface acidic sites of CoOₓ (induced by Ru SA introduction) facilitates the cleavage of C-OH bonds, ultimately leading to the formation of DMF [48]. Due to the extensive application of Ru species in the activation of different chemical bonds, furan-based platform molecules, in addition to undergoing C-O bond hydrogenolysis, are accompanied by the hydrogenation of C=C double bonds, thus generating cyclic hydrogenation products such as 2,5-dihydroxymethyltetrahydrofuran (BHTHF) and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. For example, Alamillo et al. investigated the impacts of support materials, solvent types, and liquid-phase acidity on the hydrogenation of HMF when using supported Ru, Pd, and Pt catalysts. Through their comparative analysis, it was observed that the highest yields of BHTHF-falling within the range of 88 % to 91 %-were achieved when Ru was immobilized on supports characterized by high isoelectric points. Such materials include CeO₂, MgO, ZrO₂, and γ-Al₂O₃ [49]. Tan et al. synthesized a RuPd/graphene bimetallic catalyst, which achieved a high yield of 92.9 % in the aqueous-phase hydrogenation of HMF to BHTHF, significantly higher than the yields of 6.0 % and 4.1 % obtained with the monometallic Ru/rGO and Pd/rGO catalysts, respectively; XPS results confirmed the formation of Ruᵟ⁻-Pdᵟ⁺ pairs between Ru and Pd, and the cyclic electron transfer process that occurs between these Ruᵟ⁻-Pdᵟ⁺ pairs and HMF molecules played a pivotal role in elevating the catalyst's superior activity; electron-rich Ruδ- species promote the adsorption and activation of the C=O group in HMF by donating electrons to the C=O group, and the adjacent electron-deficient Pdδ+ species achieve the adsorption and activation of the C=C group in the furan ring of HMF and BHMF molecules through accepting electrons from the C=C group (Fig. 5 ) [50]. Meanwhile, density functional theory (DFT) calculations determined HMF's adsorption energy on Pd surfaces as -0.76 eV, lower than the dissociative adsorption energy of hydrogen (-1.09 eV), indicating Pd surfaces are dominated by dissociated hydrogen atoms, thereby resulting in a low adsorption concentration of HMF; In contrast, HMF's adsorption energies on Ru and RuPd surfaces are -1.83 eV and -1.96 eV respectively, both exceeding hydrogen's adsorption energy, suggesting HMF adsorbs more readily on these two catalysts (Fig. 5 d) [50]. 3 Ru-based catalysts for HDO of Levulinic acid Levulinic acid, as an important platform chemical, was listed by the U.S. Department of Energy and the U.S. Department of Agriculture in 2004 as among the most promising derivatives of five-carbon sugars [51]. LA has received extensive attention over the years due to its broad application prospects in the production of downstream fine chemicals [52] (Fig. 6 ), such as γ-valerolactone (GVL) [53], 2-methyltetrahydrofuran [54], dihydroxyphenylacetic acid [55], and various esters [56]. Among the numerous value-added chemicals derived from LA, GVL has attracted extensive attention owning to its superior physicochemical properties, and tt finds application as a green solvent, flavoring agent, pharmaceutical intermediate, food additive, fuel additive, etc. [57]. This section focuses on discussing different Ru-based catalysts and processes for upgrading LA to GVL via HDO. The transformation of LA into GVL takes place through a two-step process: hydrogenation and dehydration. However, there remains an ongoing debate regarding whether the reaction proceeds via a pathway where hydrogenation occurs first, followed by dehydration (Path 1 in Fig. 7 ) or the reverse (Path 2 in Fig. 7) [58]. Generally speaking, it is the metallic component within the catalyst that sets off the hydrogenation of LA, whereas an acidic reaction setting serves to boost the processes of dehydration and cyclization. Ru-based catalysts have been extensively reported due to their fantastic hydrogenation performance and stability (Table 2) [59]. In 2010, Upare et al. assessed the performance of Ru/C, Pt/C, and Pd/C catalysts in the selective hydrogenation of LA to GVL, employing a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor; Their observations revealed that the Ru catalyst with high metal dispersion delivered the best catalytic results, accomplishing complete LA conversion (100 %) and full GVL selectivity (100 %) [60]. Martinelli et al. empolyed the commercial catalyst Ru/C together with the heterogeneous acid cocatalyst Amberlyst A70, and under the conditions of 3.0 MPa H₂ and 70°C, 99 mol % of GVL could be produced from LA after 3 hours of reaction [61]. Chang et al. synthesized three carbon-supported noble metal catalysts (Ru/C, Pt/C, and Pd/C) for a fixed-bed reaction system, and these catalysts efficiently catalyzed the gas-phase hydrogenation of biomass-derived LA to GVL; They found that the 5 wt % Ru/C catalyst showed higher catalytic activity and product selectivity, which was due to the better dispersion of Ru NPs on the carbon support [62]. Liu et al. developed a catalyst featuring Ru NPs embedded in mesoporous carbon (Ru-MC), which demonstrated exceptional performance in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL—boasting a TOF of 12024 h⁻¹, along with remarkable reusability (over 6 cycles) and thermal stability (up to 600°C); This superior performance arises from the embedded structure, which strengthens the interaction between Ru NPs and porous carbon, thus effectively suppressing Ru leaching and sintering (Fig. 8 a-c)[63]. Xiao et al. fabricated a catalyst consisting of Ru NPs supported on few-layer graphene (FLG). This catalyst attained 99.7 % LA conversion and 100 % GVL selectivity at room temperature under high hydrogen pressure; studies indicated that the high content of metallic Ru in Ru/FLG promoted the reaction activity (Fig. 8 d-g) [64]. Besides carbon supports, oxides themselves possess abundant Lewis acid and base sites, and can also achieve excellent dispersion of metal particles, both of which are conducive to promoting the conversion of LA to GVL [65]. Molleti et al. prepared a Ru-supported manganese oxide octahedral molecular sieve catalyst (Ru/OMS) via a solventless method, which achieved 99.9 % LA conversion and a 99.8 % GVL yield after 1 hour of reaction at 100°C [66]. Jaya et al. first prepared a Ru-supported Mg-La composite oxide catalyst using a basic support (Ru/Mg-LaO), which achieved 92 % transformation of LA to GVL with a selectivity exceeding 99 % when reacting for 4 hours in toluene as the solvent under low pressure (0.5 MPa) and low temperature (80°C) [67]. Han et al. prepared an ultrathin anatase TiO2 nanosheet decorated with Ru quantum dots (with exposed (001) facets); The high-energy (001) facets of TiO2 enhanced the interplay between the metal and the support, enabling the catalyst to convert LA into GVL at room temperature, with both conversion efficiency and selectivity surpassing 99 %; Furthermore, the catalyst can be recycled for 5 runs, and no significant decrease is observed in either the conversion of LA or the reaction selectivity [68]. The type of oxide support also exerts a significant influence on the catalytic performance of LA hydrogenation to GVL. For instance, Liu et al. loaded identical Ru NPs onto three types of TiO2 (P25, rutile, and anatase) and found that the rutile-based Ru catalyst exhibited superior catalytic stability, whereas the anatase-supported Ru catalyst showed obvious deactivation [70]. Gao et al. synthesized three Ru/CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies (nanorods, nanocubes, and nano-octahedra) for the hydrogenation of biomass-derived ethyl levulinate (EL) to GVL, and the rod-shaped Ru/CeO2 catalyst exposing the (110) crystal plane achieved the highest GVL yield (99.4 %); Experimental results confirmed that EL first undergoes hydrogenation to form 4-ethoxy-2-pentanone (EHP), followed by lactonization of EHP (Fig. 8 h-i) [75]. DFT calculations on the reaction pathway revealed that for the Ru10/CeO2 (110) catalyst, the adsorbed H2* (adsorbed hydrogen species) dissociates at Ru sites with almost no activation energy barrier. Subsequently, the carbonyl group in EL preferentially undergoes C-H bond hydrogenation with a relatively low activation energy of 0.32 eV, generating the adsorbed intermediate CH3CHOCH2CH2COOCH2CH3* (AL*). This AL* further undergoes hydrogenation to form the intermediate EHP, with an activation energy of 0.63 eV. EHP then eliminates CH3CH2O* with a reduced activation energy of 0.43 eV, followed by a dehydrogenation step to produce CH3CHOCH2CH2CO*. Finally, CH3CHOCH2CH2CO* undergoes lactonization to form GVL, with an activation energy of 0.91 eV (Fig. 8 j) [75]. Besides carbon-based and oxide supports; other carriers such as organometallic compounds and boric acid NPs have also been widely used in the LA hydrogenation reaction for GVL production. Zhang et al. employed a new stable catalyst technology to prepare a 0.85 wt % Ru/ZrO₂@C catalyst based on the metal-organic framework material UiO-66 (Zr-MOF), and contrasted its catalytic performance with that of the commercial Ru/C catalyst in the transformation of LA to GVL; Both catalysts achieved complete transformation of LA and quantitative production of GVL, but the commercial Ru/C catalyst exhibited poor deactivation resistance after a single run [76]. Zhang et al. prepared the metal-organic framework (MOF) Ru/NH2-MIL-125 as a catalyst precursor via a one-pot method, and synthesized a single-atom Ru catalyst (Ru/TiO2@CN) with ultra-low loading by high-temperature calcination at 750°C under a nitrogen atmosphere. At room temperature, the Ru/TiO2@CN catalyst showed outstanding catalytic performance for the conversion of LA, with both selectivity and yield of GVL approaching 100 %, and after three cycles of catalyst reuse, neither the catalytic activity nor the selectivity towards GVL showed a significant decrease; the TOF could reach 278 h-¹ when LA was completely converted, which exceeded that of the commercial Ru/C catalyst by approximately 35 times (Fig. 9 a-c) [77]. Feng et al. employed the zirconium-based metal-organic framework material MOF-808 to anchor metallic ruthenium. The synthesized Ru/MOF-808 composite achieved full conversion of LA alongside a GVL selectivity exceeding 99 % under mild reaction conditions; The Zr6 nodes in MOF-808 can have a high affinity with Ru particles, thereby improving the stability of Ru-based catalysts [79]. Wang et al. et al. employed a SiC-supported Ru-Ir bimetallic catalyst (Ru0.5-Ir2.5/SiC), which achieved 100 % conversion of LA under low temperature and low-pressure conditions (25°C, 0.2 MPa H₂), significantly higher than the monometallic catalysts Ir3/SiC (51.2 %) and Ru₃/SiC (45.9 %); Research has demonstrated that the high activity of the Ru0.5-Ir2.5/SiC catalyst arises from the electronic synergism between Ru, Ir, and SiC [83]. Specifically, electron-rich Ir NPs possess a greater capacity for H2 dissociation, whereas the active sites on the SiC surface serve to accommodate hydrogen species that spill over from Ir and Ru (Figs. 9 d-e) [83]. 4 Ru-based catalysts for HDO of phenolics Lignin undergoes depolymerization via hydrogenolysis, oxidation, and biological processes, yielding phenolic compounds with diverse functional groups [84]. Among these, certain compounds can be directly utilized as commercial products without further transformation; vanillin, for instance, serves directly as a fragrance and flavoring agent [85]. However, the phenolic compounds generated from lignin depolymerization contain various oxygen-containing functional groups and require further chemical or biological catalysis to be converted into end-marketable products (Fig. 10 ). Based on the specific structures of lignin-derived phenolic derivatives, value-added chemicals such as benzene, phenol, naphthenes, and cyclohexanols can be prepared through selective HDO [86]. Ruthenium-based catalysts have been employed in the research on HDO of various model compounds derived from lignin, including anisole, guaiacol, vanillin, phenol, and cresol, etc. [87]. 4.1 HDO of lignin-derived phenolics via hydrogenolysis The selective hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds is an essential HDO reaction for upgrading lignin derivatives [88]. However, lignin-derived phenolic chemicals often contain C-O bonds with varying bond energies, which results in complex reaction pathways and diverse products during the HDO process [89]. Taking the molecular structure of guaiacol, a typical lignin derivative, as an example, it contains three categories of C-O bonds: a) CAr-OH, b) CAr-OMe, and c) CMe-OCAr [90]. Due to the order of dissociation energies of these three C-O bonds (a > b > c) and the better accessibility of bond c, numerous studies have shown that guaiacol primarily undergoes dissociation of the O-CH₃ bond to generate catechol (demethylation) [91]. Meanwhile, the methyl moieties are typically converted into methane, whereas in certain specific catalytic systems, transalkylation processes may occur, generating methyl-substituted benzene ring products such as toluene, cresol, and methylcatechol [92]. Catechol can undergo further bond cleavage to yield monoxygenated compounds such as phenol, or hydrodeoxygenated hydrocarbons including benzene and cyclohexane. Specifically, the selective cleavage of bond a (dehydroxylation) and bond b (demethoxylation) both enables the formation of monoxygenated compounds (anisole and phenol). Phenol can undergo subsequent benzene ring hydrogenation to generate cyclohexanol, accompanied by the elimination of the methoxy group, which produces methanol as a high-value byproduct. Furthermore, under an atmosphere of sufficient hydrogen, guaiacol can preferentially undergo benzene ring hydrogenation to form 2-methoxycyclohexanol, followed by demethoxylation to generate cyclohexanol (Fig. 11 ). Therefore, the selective breaking of C-O bonds to generate target molecules while minimizing side reactions is critical for upgrading lignin derivatives. The design and synthesis of catalysts based on the unique electronic structure of Ru represent an important approach for the value-added utilization of lignin derivatives (Table 3). Chang et al. explored the HDO performance of Ru/C catalysts in guaiacol conversion, achieving 100 % guaiacol conversion with 69.5 % benzene selectivity under 4 MPa and temperatures below 400°C; Their research further revealed that over the Ru/C catalyst, the O-CH3 bond cleaves first to yield catechol as the key intermediate, which then undergoes dehydroxylation to produce benzene [93]. Li et al. fabricated a new Ru/LaCO3OH catalyst with excellent hydrothermal stability, featuring Ru NPs partially encapsulated by the LaCO3OH support and strong metal-support interaction, which enables the HDO of guaiacol to benzene with a 79 % yield while maintaining high stability and activity under hydrothermal reduction conditions [94]. Besides, Luo et al. prepared a hydrothermally stable catalyst Ru/HZSM-5, which could produce benzene with a selectivity as high as 95 % under aqueous phase reaction conditions (240°C, 0.2 MPa H2); Moreover, Kinetic comparisons of the individual steps in the HDO of catechol, anisole, and phenol under the same conditions confirmed that the selective hydrogenation route of guaiacol proceeds as follows: first, phenol is generated at a rate of 33 mmol·g-¹·h-¹, and then benzene is formed with a rate of 10 mmol·g-¹·h-¹ [95]. The research group further reported a Ru nanoparticle catalyst supported on HZSM-5 with a cross-shaped morphology, which exhibited a reaction rate constant of 0.051 min-¹ for converting guaiacol to benzene via hydrogenolysis—3-4 times greater than Ru/HZSM-5 with spherical or cuboid morphologies (0.012-0.029 min⁻¹); Furthermore, results from infrared spectroscopy and mass spectrometry demonstrated that the rich Lewis acid sites present on the cross-shaped HZSM-5 enhanced the adsorption capacity for guaiacol, thereby further accelerating the reaction rate [96]. Furthermore, modification and design of Ru metal active sites can alter the HDO pathway of guaiacol, thereby changing the selectivity to products. For example, Zhao’s group further synthesized RuNi bimetallic catalysts, and by regulating the H• transfer distance between Ru and Ni NPs to shorten the transfer path, they achieved the hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds in guaiacol to produce phenol at a high rate of 152 mmol·g⁻¹·h⁻¹ under low H2 pressure; Moreover, studies showed that the guaiacol hydrogenolysis rate was positively correlated with the number of adjacent RuO2 and NiO NPs in the calcined samples, indicating that the tightly adjacent Ru and Ni NPs on HZSM-5 serve as the active sites for the reaction (Figs. 12 a-b) [97]. Furthermore, the design and preparation of Ru catalysts via support engineering can also achieve the selective conversion of guaiacol to phenol. For instance, Wang et al. fabricated Ti-modified SiO2-supported catalysts (Ru/Ti-SiO2) via a simple wet impregnation method, with abundant Ti3+ defects and size-controllable Ru NPs facilitating 83.6 % guaiacol conversion and 70.4 % phenol selectivity [98]. Furthermore, Wang et al. employed a Cl-modified Ru/TiO2 catalyst, in which the Cl element electronically modifies both Ru and Ti species to induce electron enrichment of Ru, thereby inhibiting the ring hydrogenation reaction and increasing the selectivity of guaiacol conversion to phenol, which is significantly higher than that of the unmodified Ru/TiO2 catalyst [99]. Similarly, Ru-based catalysts also exhibit excellent C-O bond hydrogenolysis performance in other lignin-derived phenolic derivatives. For example, Zhang et al. loaded Ru NPs onto a composite support formed by the hybridization of niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) and micro-mesoporous carbon (MC) using the incipient wetness impregnation method, and this catalyst exhibited excellent ability to break the C-O bond of phenol to generate benzene in a decalin/water biphasic solvent [100]. Nelson et al. innovatively employed isotopic labeling and DFT calculations to explain the HDO mechanism of Ru/TiO2, demonstrating that the interfacial sites between Ru NPs and the TiO2 support, in conjunction with water functioning as a cocatalyst, synergistically facilitate the direct substitution of phenolic hydroxyl groups with hydrogen to yield benzene [101]. Huang et al. prepared a Ru-WOx bifunctional catalyst, which exhibited high catalytic activity in the aqueous-phase hydrogenolysis of diverse phenols and phenyl ethers, among which phenol could be efficiently converted to benzene with a yield as high as 77 % [102]. Tan et al. investigated the HDO mechanism of anisole on Ru and Fe metals through a combination of experimental and theoretical methods; They found that on the Ru (0001) surface, the phenoxy intermediate is hydrogenated to phenol, and the phenol can further undergo HDO to generate benzene; In contrast, on the Fe (110) surface with stronger metal oxophilicity, the C-O bond in the phenoxy group undergoes direct cleavage to generate benzene, without phenol generated [103]. Phan et al. used anisole as the reactant molecule to investigate the influence of Ru catalysts supported on three different carriers (TiO2, Al2O3, SBA-15, P25) on its reaction pathway; The study showed that Ru/SBA-15 mainly catalyzes the reaction through the hydrogenation route, and the Ru/meso-Al2O3 catalyst proceeds via both hydrogenation and demethoxylation pathways simultaneously; while Ru/meso-TiO2 and Ru/P25 generate benzene with higher yields through direct HDO [104]. In addition, the high hydrogenation activity of Ru species can be inhibited by the addition of a second metal, thereby altering the reaction pathway from benzene ring hydrogenation to direct deoxygenation. For instance, Phan et al. incorporated 1 wt % Fe into the mesoporous TiO2-supported Ru catalyst (Ru-Fe/meso-TiO2), which effectively increased the number of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst and promoted the direct deoxygenation of anisole to phenol; In contrast, the Ru/meso-TiO₂ catalyst devoid of Fe predominantly converted anisole into methoxycyclohexane [105]. Besides, Meng et al. prepared a RuW alloy nanoparticle catalyst, which achieved a selectivity to arenes as high as over 99.9 % with complete conversion of aromatic ether compounds via the self-supported hydrogenolysis (SSH) pathway of aromatic ethers; Additionally, DFT calculation studies revealed that neighboring Ru and W components within RuW alloy NPs enhance the autogenous hydrogenolysis of aromatic ethers by virtue of a cooperative interaction mechanism (Figs. 12 c-g) [106]. Mechanistic studies revealed that the reaction proceeds through the direct cleavage of Csp2-O bonds, and the synergistic effect between the hydrogenation-capable Ru sites and the Lewis acidic W sites determines the high selectivity of the reaction; DFT calculations were performed on the reaction pathway of benzene formation from anisole via the SSH reaction: first, the aliphatic C-H bond is activated to generate a C6H5OCH2 + H intermediate, and then the aromatic C-O bond in C6H5OCH2 undergoes hydrogenolysis with a cleavage energy barrier of 0.59 eV, producing benzene and formaldehyde [106]. Fine-tuning the interfacial sites between active metals and supports to regulate the product selectivity in the HDO of biomass-derived phenolic derivatives is also an efficient approach. For example, Ru nanoclusters supported on MoO3-decorated nanosized tetragonal zirconia (ZrO2) carriers catalyze anisole in the aqueous phase to produce benzene with a selectivity as high as 84.7 %, which is much higher than that of the Mo-free supported Ru catalyst (25.1 %); It is reasonable to infer that this phenomenon arises from the cooperative interaction between active Ru0 nanoclusters and beneficial interfacial Ruδ+-Ov-Mo5+ sites (where Ov denotes oxygen vacancies), which enhances the adsorption of the methoxy moiety in anisole and facilitates its demethoxylation process, ultimately leading to the formation of benzene [107]. Li et al. prepared three catalysts with different Ru0/Ruδ⁺ ratios and conducted kinetic and in-situ spectroscopic studies on the demethoxylation reaction; They found that the synergistic effect between Ru0 and Ruδ⁺ is crucial, where Ru0 is responsible for the activation of hydrogen and the adsorption of aromatic rings, while Ruδ⁺ adsorbs with the oxygen atom in the methoxyl group [108]. The Ru species in the prepared Ru/NiAl2O4-200 catalyst have a more stable electronic composition and high cyclic stability, which can effectively activate the C-O bond, rapidly recover the adsorption sites for aromatic rings, and thus exhibit excellent catalytic performance [108]. For lignin derivatives bearing multiple functional groups, such as m-cresol and 4-propylguaiacol, ruthenium-based catalysts also display superior performance in direct deoxygenation. Ren et al. used phosphorus-modified TiO2 as a support to load Ru NPs and found that this catalyst could effectively increase the conversion of m-cresol to 60 %, whereas the conversion over the Ru/TiO2 catalyst was only 0.3 %; Characterization results from CO-TPD, TEM, and XPS demonstrated that P modification could eliminate the encapsulation of Ru by TiO2 and simultaneously introduce more Brønsted acid sites, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity [109]. Fu et al. designed a solid solution Ru0.05Ce0.92O2 catalyst. Compared with Ru/SiO2, this catalyst can effectively cleave the C-OMe bond in anisole to form toluene while inhibiting the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis of C-C bonds; Among them, the Ru-OV-Ce sites serve as the active sites for deoxygenation, and the strong contact interaction in the solid solution reduces the size of Ru species, thereby hindering the hydrogenation of benzene rings [110]. Omotoso et al. investigated the active sites for the selective conversion of m-cresol to toluene through a combination of theoretical and experimental methods, and found that the perimeter of metal particles are the active sites for C-O bond cleavage; The activation energy barrier for C-O bond cleavage on the Ru surface is 1.4 eV, while it decreases to 0.7 eV at the interfacial sites, and the energy barrier for proton-assisted C-O cleavage by water molecules is further reduced to 0.3 eV [111]. Zhou et al. prepared a novel RuNi/NiAl2O4 catalyst, which can convert lignin oil to 4-propylphenol without exogenous hydrogen. The decomposition of water molecules on the Ni surface generates a small amount of hydrogen, driving the removal of methoxy groups to form 4-propylphenol and methanol, and the subsequent methanol reforming reaction further promotes the entire reaction process [112]. 4.2 HDO of lignin-derived phenolics via hydrogenation-deoxygenation When lignin-derived phenolic derivatives undergo direct C-O bond cleavage, hydrogenation of the benzene ring simultaneously occurs, yielding naphthenic hydrocarbon products, which are of great significance in resource utilization, chemical production, and energy transition [113]. A wide variety of Ru-based catalysts have been investigated and applied in the HDO of lignin derivatives [114]. Through the modification of metal sites and regulation of supports, high selectivity for the target saturated compounds has been achieved (Table 4). Song et al. explored the effect of Ru NPs with different particle sizes on the HDO of guaiacol, and found that Ru NPs with a size of 1.5 nm could efficiently convert guaiacol to cyclohexanol (yield 95 %); In situ FT-IR spectroscopy confirmed that on 1.5 nm Ru NPs, the cleavage of CAr-OCH3 bonds is prior to the hydrogenation of aromatic rings, thereby reducing the occurrence of side reactions [115]. Guvenatam et al. conducted a comprehensive exploration into how reaction parameters affect the catalytic behavior of supported Pt, Pd, and Ru catalysts during the aqueous-phase HDO of lignin model compounds; The study revealed that Pt-based and Pd-based catalysts display a higher rate of aromatic ring hydrogenation, whereas Ru/C catalyst shows a faster hydrogenation rate for the polar C=O group in cyclohexanone [116]. Nakagawa et al. performed the selective HDO of guaiacol in aqueous solution using a commercial Ru/C catalyst under a H2 pressure of 1.5 MPa. The addition of magnesium oxide (MgO) to the reaction system could suppress the unselective C-O bond cleavage, thus achieving a high yield of cyclohexanol (>80 %) [117]. Xu et al. designed a metal-solid base bifunctional catalyst, Ru/ZrO₂-La(OH)3, which catalyzes the conversion of guaiacol to cyclohexanol in an aqueous system with a yield as high as 91.6 %; For alkylphenols containing one or two methoxy groups, the yields of their conversion to alkylcyclohexanols all exceed 86.9 % [118]. Zhao et al. utilized the metal and acid bifunctional sites in the Ru/NiAl2O4 catalyst to efficiently achieve aromatic ring hydrogenation and C-O bond activation; By utilizing hydrogen exchange between water and isopropanol to facilitate in-situ hydrogen generation, they achieved a guaiacol conversion rate of up to 95 % alongside an 80 % selectivity toward cyclohexanol [119]. Gundekari et al. in situ generated a Ru(0)@Mg(OH)₂ catalyst, and by continuously and controllably introducing hydrogen at a constant temperature, they achieved complete conversion of methoxyphenols with a cyclohexanol selectivity of 93-99 % [120]. Zhang et al. designed a single-atom Ru catalyst supported on sheet CeO2 (Ru/CeO2-S), which can selectively catalyze benzene ring hydrogenation and etheric C-O(R) bond cleavage without affecting C-O(H) bonds, enabling 100 % conversion of guaiacol to cyclohexanol; Through control experiments and DFT calculations, it was revealed that the Ru-O-Ce sites in the catalyst are the key to achieving selective catalysis (Figs. 13 a-c) [121]. In-situ FT-IR spectroscopy and DFT calculations reveal that the reaction of guaiacol over the Ru/CeO₂-S catalyst proceeds via two pathways: In the first pathway, guaiacol initially undergoes stepwise hydrogenation of the benzene ring. After sequential addition of 5 hydrogen atoms, a transition state V is formed; subsequently, the C-O(CH3) bond dissociates, and the carbon atoms undergo continuous hydrogenation to generate cyclohexanol, accompanied by the conversion of the -OCH3 to methanol; In the second pathway, guaiacol can alternatively undergo continuous hydrogenation of all 6 carbon atoms on the benzene ring to form 2-MCH, thereafter, 2-MCH undergoes C-O(CH3) bond dissociation and carbon atom hydrogenation to produce cyclohexanol (Figs. 13 d-e) [121]. Zhao et al. constructed a Ru-Co alloy catalyst (Ru-Co/TiO2-Al2O3), which achieved a guaiacol conversion of ≥99 % and a cyclohexanol selectivity as high as 94 % under optimal conditions and high catalyst stability; The results demonstrated that Co doping fosters the generation of electron-enriched ruthenium, thereby expediting the desorption of active hydrogen [122]. In parallel, the TiO2-Al2O3 composite support features ample oxygen vacancies and acidic sites—both of which prove advantageous for the adsorption and hydrogenolysis of methoxy groups. (Figs. 13 f-i) [122]. Besides, complete cleavage of C-O bonds in lignin derivatives to produce cycloalkanes can also be achieved through catalyst design and condition adjustment. For example, Shu et al. prepared a highly dispersed 2wt % Ru/TiO2 catalyst, which can efficiently convert guaiacol to cyclohexane with a selectivity as high as 91.3 % at 260°C under a 1 MPa H2 atmosphere [123]. Zhang et al. designed and prepared a bifunctional catalyst (Ru/HZSM-5), in which the Brønsted acid sites within the HZSM-5 channels are responsible for dehydration, and the metallic Ru sites undertake the hydrogenation process, enabling the conversion of lignin-derived phenolic compounds to alkanes with high selectivity [124]. Similarly, A bifunctional Ru catalyst supported on H-Beta zeolite demonstrates high efficiency in eliminating oxygen-containing moieties from both monomeric and dimeric lignin-derived phenolics under moderate reaction conditions (160°C, 4 MPa H2); Notably, experimental findings reveal that the concurrent presence of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites within the zeolite framework plays a pivotal role in achieving such superior HDO performance [125]. In addition, Kim et al. prepared a bimetallic RuRe/C catalyst, where Re provides acid sites to enhance the C-O bond hydrogenolysis efficiency of guaiacol, enabling complete deoxygenation to cyclohexane (with a selectivity of 60 %); Under the same conditions, however, the product of Ru/C catalyst is cyclohexanol (with a selectivity of ≥70 %) [126]. It can be observed that, compared with the conversion of guaiacol targeting phenol as the product, the production of cyclohexanol usually requires a higher H2 pressure (1.0-3.0 MPa) and a relatively higher temperature (200-250°C). This is because a higher H2 pressure ensures sufficient H2 coverage on the catalyst surface, matching the reaction rates of hydrogenation and hydrocracking. However, excessively high pressure and temperature will lead to saturated H2 coverage on the catalyst surface, and excessive hydrogenation will cause deep deoxygenation to form cyclohexane. Similarly, Ru-based catalysts also display outstanding performance in the HDO of phenol to cyclohexanol and cyclohexane. Zhan et al. prepared a new type of composite catalyst (Ru/Nb2O5-nC18PA) via the impregnation method, and under the conditions of 12 bar hydrogen pressure and 80°C, the conversion of phenol reached nearly 100 % with a cyclohexanol yield of 93 % within 4 hours of reaction; Mechanistic studies showed that the strong binding interaction between the surface of the Ru catalyst and the benzene ring enables the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring in phenol, thereby improving the selectivity to cyclohexanol [127]. Vinokurov et al. first reported the Ru core-clay shell nanocatalysts based on tubular halloysite, which can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanol with a maximum activity (turnover frequency, TOF) as high as 17285 h-¹ [128]. Raut et al. prepared highly monodispersed Ru NPs via the wet impregnation method, and the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst achieved an 82 % conversion of phenol and a 67 % selectivity to cyclohexanone after 1 hour of reaction, 80°C and 2 MPa H₂ pressure [129]. Page et al. synthesized a bimetallic PtRu-C catalyst in the laboratory, and the rate of cyclohexane formation reached 5.05 mol·h-¹·gmetal -¹, which is higher than that of monometallic Pt-C and Ru-C catalysts [130]. Over the RuMo/NC bimetallic catalyst with isopropanol as the hydrogen source, 4-propylguaiacol can be completely converted, with the yield of 4-propylcyclohexanol reaching 70.4 %; Physicochemical analyses indicate that the catalyst’s exceptional catalytic performance stems from the homogeneous distribution and firm immobilization of nanosized electron-poor Ru species and electron-rich Mo species on the mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon support [131]. 5 Reactions of C-O/C bonds in biomass derivatives and Ru-based catalysts designed 5.1 Reactions of C-O/C bonds in biomass derivatives and active site demand The application of Ru-based catalysts in the HDO of several classic biomass derivatives (including HMF, LA, and phenolics) is summarized, which mainly involves the following two types of reactions: C-O bond cleavage and C-C bond hydrogenation. Furan-derived compounds (HMF and furfural), possess a furan ring endowed with aromaticity-like properties and electron-rich characteristics, alongside substituents including aldehyde group (-CHO) and hydroxymethyl group (-CH2OH), which necessitate a balanced coordination between Ru metallic sites and acidic sites. The cleavage of C-O bonds can be achieved through either dehydration reactions or hydrogenolysis reactions. In dehydration reactions, Brønsted acids protonate hydroxyl groups, which in turn leads to the cleavage of C-O bonds [132]. In contrast, the hydrogenolysis of C-OH bonds typically occurs at Ru0/Ru+ active sites: Ru0 sites are responsible for the dissociation of H2, while Ru⁺ sites activate C-OH bonds, thereby enabling the cleavage of C-O bonds. The preservation of C=C bonds is critical during the conversion of HMF to DMF, necessitating the implementation of strategies to either retard H2 dissociation kinetics or strengthen the activation of C-O bonds. A case in point is the selection of strong Lewis acidic supports (e.g., Nb2O5 and modified Al2O3) for fabricating Ru-based catalysts, which integrate Ru metallic sites with moderate H2 dissociation capability and Lewis acidic sites capable of specific interactions with C-O moieties. Alternatively, core-shell structured Ru catalysts with a relatively low Ru content in the shell can be engineered to reduce H2 dissociation, thereby suppressing the hydrogenation of C=C double bonds [133]. Furthermore, for the conversion of LA to GVL, the electron-deficient and adsorption-prone carboxyl and carbonyl groups of LA necessitate Ru sites with modulated electron density. Ru0 sites with mild electron deficiency (e.g., Ru-Pt alloys or Ru supported on N-doped carbon) promote preferential hydrogenation of the C=O group (avoiding decarboxylation), while Brønsted acid sites (e.g., Y-zeolite) facilitate intramolecular cyclization [134]. Similar to the reaction of converting HMF to DMF, the HDO of phenolic compounds (guaiacol, cresol) to aromatic compounds (phenol, benzene) also requires the direct cleavage of C-O bonds while avoiding the hydrogenation of the benzene ring. Ru⁰ sites drive the cleavage of C-OCH3 bonds via hydrogenolysis reactions, while Lewis acid sites (e.g., those on ZrO2, TiO2, etc.) can stabilize aromatic intermediates and inhibit the hydrogenation of aromatic rings. Especially, for the reaction of converting guaiacol to phenol, it is more suitable to prepare a catalyst that combines highly dispersed Ru sites (to expose more active Ru0 species) with weakly acidic sites; Excessively strong acidity tends to trigger the side reaction of dehydroxylation. For example, introducing electronegative elements (such as P, B) or forming alloys (such as Ru-Mo, Ru-W) can lower the d-band center of Ru and weaken its hydrogenation ability towards aromatic rings. Studies have shown that electron transfer from W to Ru in Ru-W alloys renders Ru in a slightly electron-deficient state, which not only retains the hydrogenolysis activity for C-O bonds but also inhibits excessive hydrogenation of aromatic rings [106]. Secondly, supports such as ZrO2, TiO2 or Nb2O5 are preferred, as their surface Lewis acid sites can stabilize methoxy intermediates in guaiacol through coordination, promoting polarized cleavage of C-O bonds [135]. Additionally, supports like mesoporous SiO2 or CNT can be used, where the pore confinement effect shields the contact between aromatic rings and Ru sites while allowing small methoxy groups to diffuse to active centers. However, for the selective conversion of guaiacol to saturated six-membered ring products (such as cyclohexanol and cyclohexane), the Ru metal sites are required to form strong adsorption with the conjugated π bonds of the benzene ring. For this hydrogenation process, the Ru sites must possess strong H2 dissociation capability and an adequate supply of surface hydrogen species. For the target product cyclohexanol, in the design of Ru-based catalysts, the metal sites preferably use Ru species with moderate electron density (such as Ru-Pt alloys or Ru supported on N-doped carbon) [136]. For the support, weak Lewis acid supports or those with abundant oxygen vacancies (e.g., Al2O3, CeO2) are selected; the surface active sites of these supports can activate the phenolic hydroxyl groups through coordination, thereby accelerating the hydrogenation of aromatic rings without inducing hydroxyl group removal. For the selective production of cyclohexane, the metal sites in the catalyst should employ Ru species with high density (such as Ru-Ni alloys) to enhance H2 dissociation capability, ensuring deep hydrogenation of the aromatic ring to form the cyclohexane structure [137]. Supports with both Lewis acid and weak Brønsted acid properties (e.g., Nb2O5, H-beta zeolites) are selected, where the acidic sites synergistically remove methoxy and hydroxyl groups. 5.2 Metal active sites in Ru-based catalysts The particle size and morphology of Ru metal (including single atoms, NPs, cations, and Ru alloys) as well as the interface between Ru and the support play a crucial role in the HDO of biomass derivatives. Therefore, the regulation of Ru-based active sites is a key consideration in the design and construction of Ru-based metal catalysts. Generally speaking, Ru single atoms (SA) exhibit ultra-high selectivity for activating C=O/C–OH bonds while avoiding over-hydrogenation of aromatic rings, attributed to its isolated electronic structure and strong coordination with support atoms. However, by regulating the d-orbital charge of Ru to form a Ru single-atom catalyst (SAC) with a d-electron deficiency of 1.3 e, the complete conversion of guaiacol to cyclohexanol can be achieved [138]. Ru NPs (typically 1-10 nm) exhibit excellent dissociative adsorption capacity for H2, generating highly active surface-adsorbed hydrogen species, which enables the simultaneous realization of benzene ring hydrogenation and methoxy group removal. Besides, The size of Ru NPs also influences catalytic behavior by altering the proportion of surface sites: small-sized NPs (1-3 nm) are dominated by low-coordination sites such as edges and corners, exhibiting stronger adsorption capacity for C=O bonds than aromatic rings and thus suitable for selective hydrogenation (e.g., furfural to furfuryl alcohol); medium-sized ones (3-5 nm) balance low-coordination sites and terrace sites, possessing both hydrogenation and C-O bond cleavage activity, which fits complete HDO (e.g., guaiacol to cyclohexane); large-sized particles (>5 nm) have a high proportion of terrace sites, showing strong H2 dissociation ability but poor functional group selectivity, easily triggering over-hydrogenation or carbon skeleton cleavage [139]. In Ru-based catalysts, Ru ions typically exist as a mixture of Ru⁰ and Run+ valence states. By adjusting the ratio between these two valence states, the HDO catalytic performance can be further modulated. For example, the partially reduced Ru species (Run⁺) located at ion exchange sites exhibit higher H2 adsorption activity compared to the metallic Ru0 species prepared by the impregnation method, which could improve hydrogenation activity [140]. Bimetallic catalysts prepared by alloying (such as Ru-Pt and Ru-Ni) can regulate the electron density of Ru, thereby adjusting the HDO reaction pathway. For example, Cu has higher electronegativity than Ru, causing electron transfer from Ru to Cu, which reduces Ru's electron density, weakens its ability to hydrogenate C=C bonds, and promotes the conversion of 5-chloromethylfurfural to BHMF. The geometric effect is mainly manifested in the regulation of the atomic arrangement and coordination environment of Ru active sites by the second metal, which also effect the HDO performance [141]. Compared with the single-metal Co(110) crystal plane, the construction of the RuCo alloy reduces the adsorption energy of guaiacol from 3.03 eV to 2.47 eV [142]. Furthermore, the addition of the second metal significantly enhances the hydrogen spillover phenomenon, thereby improving the HDO performance of the Ru-based catalyst. For example, the highly dispersed Ru sites and metallic Co sites on the surface synergistically promote the dissociation of H2. Through the hydrogen spillover effect, active hydrogen species can transfer from Co NPs to the defective CoO surface, thereby facilitating the HDO reaction process [142]. Owing to their unique electronic effects and geometric effects, the advantages exhibited by alloys formed by different metals with Ru are distinct. Generally, for Ru-Co/Ni bimetals, their core advantage lies in the combination of high electron density and lattice distortion, which is favorable for the HDO of lignin-derived phenolic compounds; Ru-Cu bimetals exhibit an electron-deficient effect and are suitable for the selective HDO of carbonyl compounds. 5.3 Support roles in Ru-based catalysts As we know, the selection of supports is crucial in the design of Ru-based catalysts. This review mainly summarizes the roles of four major support (carbon, oxides, zeolites, MOFs) categories in stabilizing Ru NPs, providing acid/base sites, and regulating metal-support interactions (MSI). Carbon materials (AC, CNT, and graphene), which exhibit weak metal-carbon interactions, stabilize Ru components primarily through two pathways: physical adsorption driven by pore confinement effects, or chemical modification such as N, B, or P doping—among which N-donor sites on modified carbons (e.g., N-doped CNT) can coordinate with Ru2+ precursors, not only reducing Ru particle size but also enhancing electron transfer to Ru, thereby increasing the electron density of Ru0 active species [143]. Intrinsically neutral, these carbon materials can have acid or base sites introduced via functionalization: for example, grafting -COOH groups imparts weak Brønsted acid sites, while modifying -NH2 groups introduces weak base sites [143]. Metal oxides, such as ZrO2, TiO2, and Al2O3, exhibit stronger MSI compared to carbon materials when used as supports for Ru-based catalysts. In these systems, Ru2+ species anchor to the -OH on the oxide surface through electrostatic attraction or chelation, which effectively suppresses Ru particle sintering during preparation and reaction, resulting in a Ru particle size range of approximately 1-4 nm [144]. Regarding acid-base properties, metal oxides are dominated by Lewis acid sites derived from metal cations like Zr4+, Ti4+, and Al3+; some oxides also possess weak Brønsted acid sites originating from surface hydroxyl groups, while specific oxides such as MgO feature basic sites attributed to O2- ions. Oxides MSI typically ranges from moderate to strong: reducible oxides like TiO2 and CeO2 can form a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) after high-temperature H2 reduction, where Ru sites are partially covered by TiOx or CeOx species, thereby regulating the electron density of Ru and modifying its adsorption behavior toward reactants [145]. Besides, zeolites (HZSM-5, Beta, and Y), serve as excellent supports for Ru-based catalysts, characterized by moderate MSI effect. Their microporous or mesoporous structure exerts a distinct pore confinement effect, which limits the growth of Ru NPs; meanwhile, framework Al3+ can coordinate with Ru precursors to achieve strong anchoring of Ru species [146]. In terms of acid properties, zeolites possess abundant and tunable acid sites: Brønsted acid sites originate from framework Si-OH-Al groups, while Lewis acid sites are derived from extra-framework Al3+, and both the strength and density of these acid sites can be adjusted by regulating the Si/Al ratio or via ion exchange [147]. The MSI in zeolite-supported Ru catalysts is mainly reflected in the interaction between framework oxygen atoms and Ru0, and the acid sites on zeolites can synergize with Ru metal sites to realize bifunctional catalysis; additionally, their pore structure can modulate the diffusion behavior of reactants and products [148]. MOFs, such as MOF-808, MIL-101, and ZIF-8, exhibit unique advantages as supports for Ru-based catalysts: their inherent metal clusters (e.g., the Zr6O4(OH)4 clusters in UiO-66) or organic linkers (e.g., terephthalate linkers) can coordinate with Ru precursors, enabling the formation of ultra-small Ru NPs (1-2 nm) or even single-atom Ru species [149]. In terms of acid-base properties, MOFs possess tunable acid or base sites—Lewis acid sites are typically derived from their metal clusters (e.g., Zr4+ in UiO-66), while basic sites can be introduced via amine-functionalized linkers (e.g., the imidazole rings in ZIF-8) [150]. Additionally, MOF-supported Ru catalysts feature weak to moderate MSI: the coordination between Ru and MOF metal clusters or linkers is weaker than the interaction between Ru and metal oxides, but the well-defined porous structure of MOFs significantly enhances mass transfer efficiency and selective adsorption of reactants. These characteristics make MOF-supported Ru catalysts applicable to various catalytic reactions, such as, Ru/MOF-303 for the selective hydrogenation of furfural [151]. Based on the above comparison, we will summarize actionable support selection guidelines tailored to different catalytic requirements: First, prioritize the support type based on the required acid/base properties: for reactions demanding strong Lewis acidity (e.g., C-O bond activation in HDO), select metal oxides (such as ZrO2, Nb2O5) or MOFs, as their intrinsic metal cations (Zr4+, Nb5+) provide high-density Lewis acid sites; for processes needing strong Brønsted acidity (e.g., cyclization, dehydration), choose zeolites like HZSM-5 or Beta—their framework Si-OH-Al sites offer tunable Brønsted acidity, while carbon supports should be avoided due to poor intrinsic acidity; for reactions requiring neutral or weak basic conditions (e.g., selective carbonyl hydrogenation), opt for pristine carbon (AC, CNT) or basic oxides (MgO) to minimize acid-catalyzed side reactions like etherification. Second, optimize the support for Ru nanoparticle stability: for high-temperature reactions (>300 °C), prefer oxides (TiO2, Al2O3) or zeolites, as their strong Ru-oxide anchoring or pore confinement suppresses sintering, whereas MOFs should be avoided due to thermal instability above 250 °C; for low-temperature reactions (<200 °C, e.g., LA hydrogenation), MOFs or N-doped carbon are ideal, as they enable the formation of ultra-small Ru NPs (<2 nm) for high activity without sintering risk. Third, regulate MSI to tune Ru catalytic behavior: to enhance Ru electron density (e.g., for H2 dissociation in aromatic hydrogenation), select N-doped carbon or reducible oxides (CeO2), as electron transfer from N or Ce3+ to Ru increases Ru0 activity; to suppress over-hydrogenation (e.g., furfural-to-furfuryl alcohol conversion), use TiO2 with SMSI, where TiOx overlayers reduce Ru active site accessibility and weaken aromatic ring adsorption [152]. 6 Challenges and future prospects 6.1 Challenges Ru-based catalysts, due to their excellent ability to activate chemical bonds such as C=O and C=C in HDO reactions, are frequently employed in the transformation of biomass derivatives (e.g., LA, HMF, phenols, etc.). However, they still face many challenges in practical applications, mainly reflected in the following aspects: 6.2 Stability and deactivation issues The stability of Ru-based catalysts is a core challenge restricting their industrial application, with the main deactivation mechanisms as follows: HDO of biomass derivatives often requires relatively high temperatures (e.g., > 200°C) to enhance reaction kinetics, but high temperatures will accelerate the migration and agglomeration (sintering) of Ru NPs, resulting in a decrease in the active specific surface area. For instance, in GVL production, Ru NPs may aggregate from 1-3 nm to large particles > 10 nm under high-temperature conditions, significantly reducing catalytic activity [17]. Secondly, some supports (such as TiO2) may undergo reduction during the reaction, forming TiOx overlayers that encapsulate Ru active sites, leading to a decline in activity. Research has demonstrated that Ru catalysts supported on anatase TiO2 are prone to deactivation due to SMSI during the reaction, while rutile-type supports, although more resistant, cannot completely avoid this phenomenon. Impurities such as lignin and hemicellulose in biomass feedstocks can also block Ru active sites, and by-products from excessive hydrogenation may deposit on the catalyst surface, thereby reducing activity. Besides, hydrothermal conditions (i.e., high temperature, high pressure, and aqueous environment) are a typical reaction atmosphere for HDO, and the stability of metal catalysts also remains a key challenge that requires consideration. Under hydrothermal conditions, metal atoms (e.g., Ru, Co) on the catalyst surface tend to form mobile metal ions and atomic clusters. These species diffuse to the support surface, migrate, and attach to the surface of larger particles, resulting in an increase in metal particle size, a decrease in dispersion, and ultimately a reduction in the number of active sites. Secondly, the active metal components leach out due to complexation under hydrothermal conditions: high-temperature water molecules form hydroxyl complexes with the metal surface, and these complexes detach from the support and enter the reaction liquid phase [153]. HDO reactions are typically conducted under liquid-phase or gas-phase conditions, and the differences in reaction environments lead to significant variations in the deactivation pathways of catalysts. In the liquid phase, catalyst deactivation is mainly dominated by coking and active site coverage. Coking-induced deactivation mainly occurs because liquid-phase reactants (e.g., guaiacol) or reaction intermediates (e.g., phenoxy radicals) undergo side reactions such as polymerization on active sites. These reactions generate amorphous carbon, which deposits on the catalyst surface, blocking the pores and covering the active sites of the catalyst [154]. Furthermore, solvent molecules or reactants in the liquid phase occupy the active sites of Ru metal through strong adsorption, resulting in a decrease in H2 dissociation efficiency; such active site coverage also leads to catalyst deactivation [155]. In gas-phase reactions, catalyst deactivation is more susceptible to the effects of enhanced metal oxidation and sintering [156]. If the H2 partial pressure is insufficient, or if O2 is generated from processes such as product decomposition, the active metal components will be oxidized, thereby impairing the catalytic activity. Furthermore, gas-phase reaction conditions are often accompanied by high temperatures (300-400 °C), which significantly accelerate the diffusion rate of metal atoms and thus intensify the sintering phenomenon [157]. 6.3 Difficulty in regulating selectivity Biomass-derived molecules have complex structures (e.g., HMF contains multiple functional groups such as furan ring, carbonyl group, and hydroxymethyl group), and the high hydrogenation activity of Ru-based catalysts tends to cause “over-reaction”, making it difficult to achieve high selectivity for target products: Such as, in the hydrogenation of HMF, Ru-based catalysts may simultaneously hydrogenate the furan ring, carbonyl group, and C-O bonds, resulting in decreased selectivity of target products (such as 2,5-dihydroxymethyltetrahydrofuran) and increased by-products (such as cyclic ethers and alkanes). In the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, if the reaction conditions are not properly controlled, the strong hydrogenation ability of Ru may cause GVL to further undergo ring-opening to form pentanol, reducing the yield of the target product. The HDO of guaiacol often produces various products such as benzene, phenol, and cyclohexanol, leading to difficulties in subsequent separation and purification. 6.4 Economic feasibility and large-scale production As a noble metal, Ru accounts for an excessively high proportion of catalyst costs, making it difficult to adapt to large-scale industrial production. Secondly, the reduction process of Ru precursors (such as RuCl3) requires a large amount of energy, resulting in high energy consumption in the preparation process [158]. Besides, laboratory-grade Ru-based catalysts (e.g., those prepared by impregnation) can achieve highly dispersed Ru nanoparticles (1-3 nm), but industrial production methods (such as spray drying) tend to lead to a wider particle size distribution (1-8 nm), with decreased activity and selectivity that are difficult to match the performance of laboratory-scale catalysts, thus causing difficulties in large-scale production. Ultimately, laboratory-scale reactions predominantly employ batch autoclaves with a single-batch processing volume of less than 1 liter, whereas industrial-scale operations typically utilize continuous-flow fixed-bed or fluidized-bed reactor systems. These two operational paradigms exhibit substantial discrepancies in key transport phenomena—specifically mass transfer, heat transfer—and in the modes of contact between reactants and catalysts. For example, the intense collision of catalysts in fluidized beds can cause metal catalysts to detach from the support surface, which in turn leads to the loss of active components. 6.5 Harsh reaction conditions Ru-based catalysts often require high-pressure H2 (e.g., >2 MPa) and relatively high temperatures to achieve efficient HDO. This not only increases equipment costs and operational risks but may also exacerbate catalyst deactivation (such as sintering and support degradation). How to maintain high activity under mild conditions (e.g., room temperature, low-pressure H2) is an important direction for the practical application of Ru-based catalysts. 6.6 Future prospects The challenges of Ru-based catalysts in the HDO of biomass derivatives—encompassing stability, selectivity, economic feasibility, and reaction conditions—require synergistic breakthroughs across catalyst design, reaction mechanism, and process optimization. Future research may focus on the following directions: (1) Precise regulation of catalyst structure. a) Construction of bimetallic/multimetallic synergistic systems: By constructing alloy/heterostructures of Ru with other noble metals (Pd, Pt) or non-noble metals (Co, Ni, Cu), the HDO activity and selectivity of the catalyst can be enhanced through electronic and geometric effects between multiple metals. For instance, Ru-Co alloys can reduce the excessive adsorption of intermediates by Ru, and Co can enhance the ability to break C-O bonds, thereby inhibiting side reactions (such as ring opening). b) Functional modification of supports: Developing novel supports (such as graphene, MOFs/COFs-derived materials, and heteroatom-doped materials) to stabilize Ru nanoparticles (inhibiting sintering/leaching) and selectively adsorb specific functional groups of biomass derivatives (e.g., furan rings, carbonyl groups) by regulating the acidity-basicity, reducibility, defect sites, hydrophobicity of supports or their SMSI with Ru, thereby enhancing the selectivity of target products. For example, supports with high oxygen vacancies can effectively anchor metallic Ru and improve the adsorption of C-O bonds in phenolic compounds. c) Single-atom and atomically dispersed catalysts: Dispersing Ru into single atoms or sub-nanoclusters to maximize atomic utilization (reducing Ru dosage), while improving stability through support anchoring (e.g., defect sites, heteroatom coordination). For instance, single-atom Ru supported on ceria with abundant oxygen vacancies can suppress multiple reaction pathways in the HDO of guaiacol, significantly enhancing the selectivity of target products. (2) Mechanistic understanding. In situ techniques (e.g., XAS, IR, Raman) combined with DFT calculations can unravel the dynamic evolution of Ru active sites (e.g., valence state, coordination environment) and substrate adsorption/activation pathways. For example, clarifying the competitive adsorption between furan ring and carbonyl group in HMF hydrogenation enables the design of Ru sites with preferential carbonyl hydrogenation. Additionally, tuning catalyst surface/interface properties (e.g., acid strength, electron density, defect concentration) can regulate intermediate formation and conversion. For instance, in guaiacol HDO, Ru-based catalysts with weak hydrogenation activity but strong C-O bond cleavage capability (e.g., Ru supported on weakly acidic carriers) are required to inhibit benzene ring hydrogenation (preserving aromaticity) and achieve selective C-O bond cleavage. (3) Process greening. The design of highly active and multifunctional catalysts enables efficient HDO under low temperature (<100°C) and low pressure (<1 MPa H₂), reducing energy consumption and equipment costs while mitigating catalyst sintering caused by high temperatures. Secondly, liquid hydrogen donors such as isopropanol can replace high-pressure hydrogen to enhance safety and reduce costs. Developing green solvents (e.g., water) or solvent-free systems helps minimize catalyst poisoning. Shortening the process flow by integrating biomass hydrolysis pretreatment and HDO into a "one-pot" process to reduce intermediate separation steps can also lower costs and realize process greening. Through the aforementioned multi-dimensional research and innovation, it is expected to break through the application bottlenecks of Ru-based catalysts in biomass HDO, promote their transition from laboratory research to industrial application, and provide core support for the efficient conversion of biomass resources and sustainable energy production. 6.7 Conclusion In recent years, numerous studies have been reported on the HDO of biomass derivatives. Among various catalysts, Ru exhibits outstanding catalytic activity. This review focuses on Ru-based catalysts for the selective HDO of biomass derivatives (furans, LA, phenolics), with emphasis on the design and innovation of Ru-based catalysts and their selectivity in targeted HDO reactions (C-O bond cleavage, C=C bond hydrogenation). By integrating insights from fundamental research and advancements in practical applications, this work aims to inspire researchers to further explore Ru-based compounds as highly promising alternative catalysts. Such efforts are expected to open up new pathways for biomass HDO, lay a foundation for the sustainable development of biomass refining, and promote the advancement of circular bioeconomy. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a key catalytic process for upgrading biomass derivatives into high-value biofuels and chemicals, providing a sustainable alternative to fossil fuel-based production. Among numerous catalytic systems, ruthenium (Ru)-based catalysts have attracted considerable attention due to their excellent activity, selectivity, and stability in cleaving C-O bonds under relatively mild reaction conditions. This review comprehensively summarizes the recent research progress in the application of Ru-based catalysts for the HDO of various biomass derivatives, including furans, carboxylic acids, and phenolics. We systematically discuss the influence of Ru-based catalyst design parameters (such as metal particle size, electronic state, and support properties) on the directed HDO of biomass derivatives. In addition, this review elaborates on the possible reaction mechanisms of Ru-based catalysts in the HDO process. Finally, the challenges and opportunities faced in this interesting and important research field are prospected, aiming to promote the practical application of Ru-based catalysts in sustainable biomass conversion.
